<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_register_generic_device:
```c
int metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	if (!device->name || !strlen(device->name) ||
	    device->num_regions > METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS)
		return -EINVAL;

	device->bus = &metal_generic_bus;
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_device_list,
			    &device->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
!strlen(device->name)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Calling strlen(device->name) only checks for a non-NULL pointer but does not ensure the character array is null-terminated within its bounds. If device->name points to a char buffer that lacks a terminating '\0' (or points into memory such that no '\0' exists before the end of the object), strlen will read past the object’s bounds, violating Rule 21.17.
